abstract:
The RBT (River Buffer Toolkit) is a set of tools designed for analyzing river channels using Geographic Information System (GIS) software within ESRI's ArcGIS Desktop. These tools help users understand and measure the physical attributes of river channels using high-resolution Digital Elevation Models (DEMs). DEMs can be obtained from airborne sensors like LiDAR or ground surveys.

The RBT offers several key capabilities: 
1. It removes longitudinal valley slope to analyze channel geometry more accurately.
2. Users can create cross sections and determine hydraulic geometry metrics, such as bankfull width/depth.
3. The tool computes stream gradient and sinuosity.
4. Long profiles are generated to examine longitudinal variations in channel geometry metrics.
5. Water levels can be adjusted within the detrended DEM for insight into water depth distribution and off-channel habitats connected to the main stem flow.
6. Residual pools, which may indicate fish habitat, are identified.

The RBT is an ArcGIS extension, meaning it requires an existing installation of ESRI's ArcGIS software before usage. For more information, consult the provided resources at: http://essa.com/tools/RBT/highlight/ and http://www.monitoringmethods.org/Method/Details/836

This method is crucial for river management as it provides an efficient and accurate means to analyze various aspects of river channels. The RBT's advanced tools address the challenges faced when dealing with large volumes of data or manually analyzing complex topographic features, ultimately contributing to improved understanding of river behavior and effective conservation efforts.
description:
The River Bathymetry Toolbox (RBT) is a set of extensions for ESRI's ArcGIS Desktop software that enables users to analyze and measure river channels using high-resolution Digital Elevation Models (DEMs). These DEMs can be derived from airborne remote sensing, such as Light Detection and Ranging (LiDAR) data or ground-based topographic surveys. The RBT offers several functionalities:

1. **Detrend a DEM**: This process is used to eliminate longitudinal valley slope from the DEM to facilitate more accurate analysis of the river channel.
2. **User-defined cross sections**: Users can extract cross-sections through the DEM at specified locations for detailed examination of the river geometry.
3. **Hydraulic geometry definition**: For each cross section, users can define and measure parameters such as bankfull width and depth.
4. **Stream gradient and sinuosity computation**: These important metrics are calculated from the channel's longitudinal profile to understand its shape and behavior.
5. **Longitudinal profiles**: Long profiles can be extracted along a river channel to study variations in any of the geometry metrics over long distances.
6. **Water level variation**: Users can simulate different water levels within a detrended DEM to explore the distribution of water depths inside a stream and assess off-channel habitat still hydraulically connected to the main stem flow.
7. **Residual pool identification**: These features, which may serve as fish habitats, can be located using RBT's tools.

Please note that to use the RBT, you must have ESRI ArcGIS Desktop software installed on your system beforehand. For further details and resources, refer to the official RBT documentation at http://essa.com/tools/RBT/highlight/. Additionally, for understanding the collection of measurement data used in the calculation process, consult the CHaMP - Topographic Point Collection Methods documentation at http://www.monitoringmethods.org/Method/Details/836.
